Introduction

Antiemetics are medications used to prevent or alleviate nausea and vomiting, which can result from a variety of causes, including chemotherapy, postoperative states, vestibular dysfunction, gastrointestinal irritation, CNS pathology, and pregnancy.  Antiemetic drugs act on a variety of receptors involved in the emetic reflex arc.  These receptors include serotonin 5-hydroxytryptamine type 3 (5-HT3), dopamine type 2 (D2), histamine type 1 (H1), muscarinic acetylcholine (M1), and neurokinin-1 (NK1) receptors.  Identifying the underlying cause of nausea and vomiting helps in the selection of antiemetic therapy.

Pathophysiology



Nausea and vomiting are coordinated reflexes involving complex interactions between the gastrointestinal system and the CNS.  Neuroanatomic structures involved in nausea and vomiting include the following (

Physiologic causes of nausea
):



  • Chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ):  Located in the area postrema of the medulla, the CTZ is outside the blood-brain barrier and detects circulating emetogenic substances (eg, drugs, toxins, metabolic by-products), which activate D2 receptors, 5-HT3 receptors, and NK1 receptors (to which substance P binds) in the CTZ.  The CTZ can also be triggered by vagal afferents from the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Vomiting center:  This complex network of neurons is located in the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) of the medulla oblongata of the brainstem.  It coordinates the act of vomiting through the integration of signals from various sources (eg, gastrointestinal tract, vestibular system, CTZ).
  • Vestibular system:  The vestibular apparatus in the inner ear can trigger vomiting through the vestibular nuclei.  This pathway is mediated by H1 and M1 receptors and is particularly relevant in motion sickness.
  • Vagal and enteric afferents:  Irritation or distension of the gastrointestinal tract can activate vagal afferent fibers that transmit signals to the brainstem.  This process involves the release of serotonin from enterochromaffin cells, which stimulates 5-HT3 receptors on the vagal afferents.
  • Cerebral cortex and higher centers:  Psychologic factors (eg, stress, fear) and sensory inputs (eg, unpleasant sights or smells) can activate higher brain centers, which then communicate with the vomiting center in the medulla to induce vomiting.


Disruption or stimulation of any of these pathways can provoke nausea and vomiting, which is why antiemetic agents may be selected to target multiple receptors depending on the clinical context.

Classes of antiemetics and mechanisms of action

5-HT3 receptor antagonists



Common 5-HT3 receptor antagonists include ondansetron, granisetron, dolasetron, and palonosetron.



  • Central action:  These drugs inhibit 5-HT3 receptors in the CTZ, reducing the brain's response to circulating emetogenic substances and thereby suppressing nausea and vomiting.
  • Peripheral action:  5-HT3 receptor antagonists block serotonin receptors on vagal afferent nerves in the gastrointestinal tract, preventing emetogenic signalsâ€”triggered by chemotherapy and other stimuliâ€”from reaching the brainstem vomiting center.


Studies have not shown a significant difference in efficacy or tolerance between the 3 first-generation agents (ondansetron, granisetron, dolasetron).  Palonosetron has a higher receptor binding affinity and much longer half-life.

D2 receptor antagonists



Three classes of dopamine receptor antagonists are commonly used in patients with nausea or vomiting: phenothiazines, butyrophenones, and benzamides.



  • Phenothiazines (eg, prochlorperazine, chlorpromazine):  Their primary mechanism of action is antagonizing D2 receptors in the CTZ.  They also have M1 and H1 receptorâ€“blocking effects.
  • Butyrophenones (eg, haloperidol, droperidol):  These medications work primarily by blocking D2 receptors in the CTZ.  At higher doses, they may also block alpha-adrenergic, H1, and M1 receptors, which can lead to hypotension, sedation, and anticholinergic adverse effects.
  • Benzamides (eg, metoclopramide):  Metoclopramide, the most commonly used drug in this class, causes central and peripheral D2 antagonism at low doses and weak 5-HT3 blockade at higher doses.  It also stimulates cholinergic receptors on gastric smooth muscle cells, enhancing gastric motility and accelerating gastric emptying.  This action helps alleviate nausea and vomiting associated with gastroparesis and other gastrointestinal disorders.  Trimethobenzamide and domperidone are 2 other benzamide antiemetics.  Trimethobenzamide has limited efficacy, and domperidone is a peripherally acting D2 antagonist that avoids central adverse effects.


Although all 3 classes of dopamine antagonists target D2 receptors, their differing receptor profiles and adverse effect risks make them useful in distinct clinical contexts.

Antihistamines (H1 antihistamines)



The first-generation antihistamines diphenhydramine, meclizine, and hydroxyzine are commonly used to treat nausea related to motion sickness, vertigo, and migraines.



  • Central action:  They block H1 receptors in the vestibular nuclei and the vomiting center, reducing neuronal excitability and suppressing input from the vestibular system to the emetic pathways.
  • Additional actions:  Many also have anticholinergic (M1 receptor-blocking) activity, which further contributes to their antiemetic effects, especially in motion-induced nausea.


These drugs are most effective for vestibular-related nausea and are often used prophylactically for motion sickness but may cause sedation and anticholinergic adverse effects.

Anticholinergics (muscarinic antagonists)



Scopolamine is the major anticholinergic drug that is effective as an antiemetic.  It is typically applied as a transdermal patch behind the ear.



  • Central action:  Scopolamine inhibits M1 receptors in the vestibular nuclei and the vomiting center, reducing the excitability of those structures, thereby preventing initiation of the vomiting reflex.
  • Peripheral action:  Scopolamine reduces gastrointestinal motility and secretions by blocking M1 receptors in the gastrointestinal tract.


Scopolamine is particularly effective for motion sickness and vestibular-related nausea.  Its transdermal delivery system provides sustained antiemetic effects (up to 72 hr).

NK1 receptor antagonists



NK1 receptor antagonists include the oral agent aprepitant and its parenteral version fosaprepitant, netupitant (which is available in combination with palonosetron), and rolapitant.



  • Central action:  They prevent substance P from binding to NK1 receptors in the NTS and CTZ (area postrema), thereby inhibiting the transmission of emetic signals to the vomiting center in the medulla.
  • Additional actions:  NK1 receptor antagonists can modulate vagal afferent activity and enhance the antiemetic efficacy of other agents (eg, 5-HT3 receptor antagonists, corticosteroids).


These drugs typically work best in combination with serotonin receptor antagonists and dexamethasone.

Cannabinoids



The synthetic cannabinoids dronabinol and nabilone are oral agents approved for the treatment of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.  They are particularly useful when symptoms are unresponsive to standard therapies.



  • Central action:  Cannabinoids activate cannabinoid (CB1) receptors in the CNS, particularly within the vomiting center and the dorsal vagal complex, which suppresses nausea and vomiting by inhibiting neurotransmitter release involved in the emetic reflex.
  • Peripheral action:  Cannabinoids activate CB1 receptors on the vagal afferent nerves, which modulate the release of neurotransmitters from the enterochromaffin cells, reducing the release of serotonin, a potent emetic agent.


Cannabinoids are typically reserved for refractory nausea and, although effective, are associated with psychotropic adverse effects (eg, dizziness, euphoria, dysphoria), which may limit their use in some patients.

Corticosteroids



Dexamethasone is the most common corticosteroid used in the management of nausea and vomiting.



  • Central action:  Dexamethasone exerts antiemetic effects by modulating neurotransmission in the NTS and CTZ, likely through glucocorticoid receptor activation, inhibition of substance P/NK1 signaling, and reduced serotonin release.
  • Additional actions:  It decreases inflammation and edema in the gastrointestinal tract and CNS, stabilizes the blood-brain barrier, and enhances the efficacy of other antiemetics (eg, 5-HT3 receptor antagonists, NK1 receptor antagonists).


Corticosteroids are most effective when used in combination therapy and are generally well tolerated in the short term.

Other drugs

Olanzapine



The use of atypical antipsychotics has increased in the prevention and treatment of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.  Olanzapine has a broad receptor profile.  It antagonizes several neurotransmitter receptors involved in the emetic pathways:



  • D2 receptors.
  • Serotonin 5-HT2A and 5-HT3 receptors.
  • H1 receptors.
  • M1 receptors.


This multireceptor blockade allows olanzapine to provide both central and peripheral antiemetic activity.  It is used primarily as part of a 4-drug regimen for highly emetogenic chemotherapy, often with a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist, dexamethasone, and an NK1 receptor antagonist.  It is generally well tolerated in short-term antiemetic use.  Adverse effects may include sedation, dizziness and hypotension, dry mouth, constipation, increased appetite, and extrapyramidal symptoms.

Promethazine



Promethazine is a phenothiazine derivative that differs from the other phenothiazines.



  • It is a weak dopamine D2 antagonist, which is why it lacks antipsychotic properties and has a low risk for extrapyramidal symptoms.
  • Promethazine is a potent H1 receptor blocker, contributing to its strong sedative and antiemetic effects, whereas most other phenothiazines have only moderate H1 activity.
  • It strongly antagonizes M1 receptors, leading to anticholinergic adverse effects (eg, dry mouth, constipation) and enhancing its antinausea action.  This anticholinergic effect is generally less pronounced in other phenothiazines.


This multireceptor blockade allows promethazine to exert both central and peripheral antiemetic effects, particularly in the vestibular system and CTZ.  Promethazine is especially effective for motion-related nausea and is often used as monotherapy or as an adjunct to other antiemetics.  It is generally well tolerated but is known for its sedative properties due to strong H1 and anticholinergic activity.  Caution is required in children under age 2 due to the risk for respiratory depression, and intravenous promethazine should be administered carefully to avoid tissue injury.

Indications



Antiemetic selection is guided by the underlying cause of nausea and vomiting, with specific drug classes preferred for different clinical scenarios (

).

Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV) and radiation-induced nausea and vomiting (RINV)



Patients undergoing chemotherapy or radiation often require aggressive antiemetic prophylaxis due to stimulation of multiple emetic pathways, including serotonin, substance P, and dopamine.



  • Acute CINV/RINV (<24 hr):  5-HT3 receptor antagonists are first-line.  They may be combined with dexamethasone to improve their effectiveness.
  • Delayed CINV (>24 hr):  NK1 receptor antagonists are particularly effective.  These are commonly used as part of a triple therapy regimen with the 2 classes (5-HT3 receptor antagonists, dexamethasone) previously discussed.


Combining drugs that target different receptor pathways enhances efficacy.

Postoperative nausea and vomiting



A frequent and significant complication following anesthesia and surgery, particularly among high-risk individuals (eg, female patients, nonsmokers, those with a history of motion sickness or perioperative opioid use).



  • First-line:  5-HT3 receptor antagonists.
  • Adjuncts/alternatives:
    • Dexamethasone (administered at anesthesia induction).
    • Droperidol.
    • Scopolamine patch.


A multimodal approach is often used in high-risk individuals (eg, 5-HT3 antagonist + dexamethasone Â± scopolamine).

Motion sickness and vestibular disorders



First-line treatments include antihistamines (eg, meclizine) and anticholinergics (eg, scopolamine patch).  These agents are most effective when administered prophylactically before exposure to motion or vestibular triggers.



Gastrointestinal causes



The preferred agents are dopamine antagonists (eg, metoclopramide, prochlorperazine) for gastrointestinal conditions (eg, gastroenteritis, gastroparesis).  5-HT3 receptor antagonists may also be used.  Metoclopramide can be administered because it promotes gastric emptying and is particularly helpful in patients with gastroparesis.

Migraine-associated nausea



Dopamine antagonists (eg, prochlorperazine, metoclopramide) are particularly useful because they address both central emetic pathways and migraine pain, making them a practical and dual-purpose option.  Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and triptans should be coadministered to treat the headache component.

Pregnancy-related nausea and vomiting



Nausea and vomiting affect up to 70%â€“80% of pregnant individuals.  Management focuses on symptom control while minimizing fetal risk (

figure 2
).



  • First-line treatment is dietary modification (eg, small, frequent meals; bland foods; avoidance of food triggers).
  • If symptoms do not improve, oral vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) is prescribed.  Doxylamine succinate, an oral H1 antihistamine, can be added for enhanced therapeutic effect.
  • Other oral H1 antihistamines (eg, diphenhydramine, dimenhydrinate) are second-line therapies.


Early and effective intervention improves maternal comfort and may also prevent progression to hyperemesis gravidarum, a condition associated with dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, and weight loss.

Safety, adverse effects, and monitoring



Antiemetics vary widely in their adverse effect profiles and monitoring requirements.  Adverse effects vary, depending not only on the class of drug, but also the specific drug within that class (

).

5-HT3 receptor antagonists



This class of medications is generally well tolerated.  Most have a rapid onset of action and are associated with minimal sedation.  Serious adverse effects include the following:



  • QT prolongation and torsades de pointes:  These medications can prolong the QT interval in a dose-dependent manner, increasing the risk for torsades de pointes.  This risk is particularly significant in patients with congenital long QT syndrome, electrolyte abnormalities, congestive heart failure, or concurrent use of other QT-prolonging drugs.  ECG should be monitored in patients with known QT risk.
  • Serotonin syndrome:  Use of 5-HT3 receptor antagonists, especially with other serotonergic drugs (eg, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors), can lead to serotonin syndrome.
  • Constipation:  Slowed colonic transit can occur due to the presence of 5-HT3 receptors on enteric neurons.


Other common adverse effects include headache and dizziness.

D2 receptor antagonists



Several serious and potentially irreversible adverse effects can occur with the use of dopamine antagonists.



  • Extrapyramidal symptoms:  Acute dystonia, akathisia, and parkinsonism (especially with metoclopramide).  These symptoms occur because of D2 blockade in the nigrostriatal pathway.
  • Tardive dyskinesia:  A serious and potentially irreversible adverse effect of long-term use, particularly with metoclopramide.
  • QT prolongation:  A rare but possible adverse effect.  Droperidol has a black box warning regarding the risk for sudden cardiac death.  The FDA advises ECG monitoring for arrhythmias for 2-3 hours after administration.  This class of medication should be avoided in patients with an increased risk for QT prolongation.


Other adverse effects include sedation (more common with promethazine) and anticholinergic effects (eg, dry mouth, constipation, urinary retention).

Antihistamines and anticholinergics



These medications have similar adverse effect profiles.



  • Sedation:  A common adverse effect due to central H1 receptor blockade; especially prominent with diphenhydramine and promethazine.
  • Anticholinergic effects (eg, dry mouth, blurred vision, urinary retention, constipation):  More pronounced with scopolamine and promethazine.
  • Dizziness and confusion:  Common adverse effects, especially in older adults.
  • Paradoxical excitation:  Effect occasionally seen in children with diphenhydramine use.
  • Local skin reactions:  Irritation at the application site with a scopolamine patch.


Scopolamine should be used cautiously in the elderly due to the risk for delirium from central anticholinergic activity.

NK1 antagonists



This class of medications is generally well tolerated.  Some potential adverse effects include:



  • Fatigue and dizziness:  Common but generally mild and transient.
  • Hiccups:  Frequently reported, especially with aprepitant, although usually benign.
  • Elevated liver enzymes:  Possible mild transaminase elevation, particularly with repeated dosing.
  • Gastrointestinal effects:  Nausea, constipation, or diarrhea, which may occur despite treatment.
  • Neutropenia:  A rare adverse effect.  Routine monitoring of blood counts is recommended when NK1 antagonists are used with other chemotherapeutic agents that also suppress bone marrow function.


Aprepitant is a moderate CYP3A4 inhibitor that can affect the metabolism of other drugs such as dexamethasone, warfarin, and certain chemotherapeutic agents.

Cannabinoids



Cannabinoids have been used for centuries for their medicinal properties, including appetite stimulation and relief of nausea.  Although generally well tolerated, they carry a unique set of adverse effects related to their psychoactive and autonomic effects.



  • CNS effects:  Drowsiness, dizziness, euphoria, dysphoria, and impaired concentration.
  • Cognitive and psychiatric symptoms:  Anxiety, hallucinations, and paranoia, especially at higher doses or in older adults.
  • Increased appetite and dry mouth:  Frequently observed and may be desirable or undesirable depending on the patient.
  • Orthostatic hypotension and tachycardia:  Especially with rapid dose escalation.
  • Potential for abuse or dependence:  Due to cannabinoids' psychoactive properties, although the risk is lower in medically supervised use.


Cannabinoids should be used cautiously in those with a history of psychiatric illness or substance use disorders.

Corticosteroids



Long-term use of corticosteroids is associated with a wide range of adverse effects (eg, insomnia, hyperglycemia, gastric upset, fluid retention, immunosuppression).  However, when used for nausea (eg, chemotherapy, postoperative settings), they are typically given short term and are well tolerated.  Dexamethasone is a key component of multimodal antiemetic therapy, and short-term use is usually well tolerated.

Summary



Antiemetic medications (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
) reduce nausea and vomiting by targeting specific receptors involved in the emetic reflex arc.  These receptors are located in areas such as the chemoreceptor trigger zone, the vestibular system, and the gastrointestinal tract.  They include:



  • 5-Hydroxytryptamine type 3 (5-HT3) receptor antagonists block serotonin at both central and peripheral receptors and are used primarily for chemotherapy-induced, radiation-induced, and postoperative nausea and vomiting.  Common adverse effects include headache, constipation, and QT-interval prolongation, which may increase the risk for arrhythmias in susceptible patients.
  • Dopamine type 2 (D2) receptor antagonists (eg, metoclopramide, prochlorperazine) inhibit D2 in the chemoreceptor trigger zone and are used mainly for postoperative nausea, migraine-associated nausea, and gastroparesis-related symptoms.  These agents carry a higher risk for extrapyramidal symptoms (eg, dystonia, akathisia, parkinsonism), sedation, and, with prolonged use, tardive dyskinesia.
  • Histamine type 1 (H1) antihistamines (eg, promethazine, diphenhydramine) block H1 receptors in the vestibular system and brainstem.  They are especially effective for motion sickness and vestibular disorders such as vertigo.  Because of their strong anticholinergic activity, they often cause drowsiness, dry mouth, dizziness, and blurred vision.
  • Anticholinergics (eg, scopolamine) inhibit muscarinic cholinergic transmission in the vestibular nuclei and brainstem.  They are most commonly used for the prevention of motion sickness and postoperative nausea.  Adverse effects include dry mouth, visual disturbances, urinary retention, and confusion, particularly in elderly patients.
  • Neurokinin-1 (NK1) receptor antagonists (eg, aprepitant, fosaprepitant) block substance P from binding to NK1 receptors in the brainstem.  These drugs are used primarily for preventing chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, typically with 5-HT3 antagonists and corticosteroids.  They are generally well tolerated, but adverse effects include neutropenia and hiccups.


Antiemetic therapy can be targeted to the clinical context.
